how did it start what makes it a startup well one thing was vc funding from the us

the idea that it's completely novel uh anymore to patent any bit of software it makes me

three weeks instead of like four days to do a sample demo application it became unfeasible even just write a

were recording every hour we were spending during the day and which customer we
we were working for so that they could build accurately and that was a weird thing because i'd never experienced that sky
sky had just said well you're a central resource that sky news and sky sport and
everyone can use we just fund it out of the graphic design budget for the whole of the
company and what they need you give them and if you need more money for equipment and stuff the channels
will pay for it if it's hardware and they'll probably pay a little bit more to do overtime to do projects but
it was a centrally allocated budget so in this time sheet world because obviously i wasn't uh working
too hard because they hadn't really got a job for me in a way they realized there were people who weren't working and um
and if you're not working that's a bit of a waste so if there's a project going on
and you aren't allocated to it but you haven't got any other work maybe maybe you could work on that project and
that's a good idea right so but then the human mentality came in
and they gained the system so project managers and product managers would actually not include things like
an architect on a project so that you were left idle so they could then bring you in at zero cost later on
in the project and it was just a fascinating insight into human behavior at that point
and that really isn't a start-up idea that isn't really how startups are meant to work

so the head of design really wanted us to have um a kind of on-brand message so

not quite the right orange and so for a cost of about 10 000 pounds we all had
to move all our deaths again get painters back in repaint all the columns so that when the paint dried out

so the other thing that i saw is i'd spent years at bskyb working on interactive tv applications
two three years and i was used to how hard they are it's like programming a washing machine
there is hardly any memory the graphics are very poor the performance of the box isn't very good
uh and that may sound really weird and why on earth would you do that well if my set top box costs me an extra

that kind of money that's quite a lot of money to spend just so that your applications

so people don't do that but yet i was watching a demo written in macromedia director

before uh the end came we were working on a big project for british telecom so
that's like i think nortel is your telecom company in norway or telefonica in spain something like that
and they wanted to roll out video on demand this was 2001 they were going to roll out effectively netflix

no i just needed a few things from my desk and basically she had actually emptied her desk that

on the monday so one piece of advice i would always say to you that if your financial controller or your
chief of finance takes all the stuff off their desk and goes home with it one day you ought to do the same because you

a breakfast tv company in the uk he ran an i.t services arm he put in

and they'd gone and hired the smash latin network engineer they brought me in to do the work on

and we were negotiating a share of income from the sms messages so that we would be paid for how busy the service
was and this is where i realized how good it was to have someone experienced in business and contracts
because my business partner was was not convinced and it's not the first time by the way
in a startup i've seen a spreadsheet that had fanciful projections or optimistic
projections is more what the project manager would normally say that suggested there were going to be
millions of messages and there will be lots of money flowing and therefore we were going to get very rich by just getting one tenth of one pence
of every message and we were going okay we get one you know one tenth of a penny per
message there's millions of messages this is worth quite a lot and they said yes you're you're going to
be earning at least 600 000 a year off this and it's worth doing this and you're not going to get paid
properly to write it you're going to get paid as a as a kind of revenue share and we said well we'll put a minimum in
that shall we and they said well you don't need a minimum it's guaranteed this is going to work really well
but my business part was quite keen on a minimum so he put the minimum about a third the estimate of what we
were going to earn and doing that meant we had to send our source code to a lawyer so i
got to find out what escrow was how a lawyer could keep your source code in their safe available and you had to
update it regularly and we had to pay for that lawyer to be able to do this um so that if we went bankrupt uh you
media could own the code which is a you know a reasonable protection for a partner that
you're working with and this is not an uncommon thing to do in the industry
the business realities which is the crazy shirt is we had that minimum guarantees but skye
decided we weren't going to use sms to do messages we were going to use the built-in application and use the remote
control and it had the remote control had the letters on it like you had on old phones and it didn't have t9 so it
took ages to type a message on that set-top box you could buy a keyboard but the only people who seemed to buy the keyboards
for the set-top box were developers of applications who said how great it was to have a keyboard but no one at home
spent 30 pounds having a keyboard to talk to their set-top box so this meant the services were much
less popular they were every day on sky news they were also on sky one events and on some live sport but the shortfall
was massive we had nothing like the throughput of messages that we were meant to get so new media realized this and said this
is really bad we needed bskyb as a big client so that's why we want to get the contract
but we don't really want to pay this money out on this minimum guarantee and they knew that every time
we gave them an invoice we had to pay vat on it so we gave them invoice for fifty thousand pounds we had to pay the
government ten thousand pounds on top for the vat so they tried to not pay
invoices so that we would go bankrupt by having to pay the vat tax bills to the government
and pay the employees wages and the overheads of having an office and all sorts of things and they were trying to trigger the
clause to provide the source code so we were actually being forced to go bankrupt in order to get hold of the
source code for our our software and avoid paying the 200 000 the really good news was that
my business part had loads of money in the bank and carried on regardless and just kept the money flowing until we
got lawyers involved and got them to pay the money and in the end of it in the year that sky had the service we
got approximately quarter of a million pounds for providing that service uh from new media who probably got no
more than 10 to 20 000 pounds back from uh from the actual messages and uh contracts from sky
and the amazing bit was we wondered how we'd managed to get away with this even though it seemed you know it was good
negotiation uh by my business partner it was very odd that they agreed to this and we
